EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

The County Sanitation Districts of Los Angeles County (referred to hereinafter as the CSDLAC) owns and operates the San Jose Creek Water Reclamation Plant (SJCWRP).  The San Jose Creek Water Reclamation Plant is broken into two sub-facilities designated as the East and West Facility.

The San Jose Creek Water Reclamation Plant East (SJCWRP East) is located at 1965 Workman Mill Road in Whittier, California 90601.  The SJCWRP East facility stores a maximum of 72,000-pounds of chlorine at any one time (contained in two 25-ton bulk storage containers located indoors), a maximum of 68,000 pounds of sulfur dioxide at any one time (contained in two 20-ton bulk storage containers located indoors), and a maximum of 130,000 pounds of aqueous ammonia (19.5 percent concentration) at any one time (contained in three 6,180 gallon above-ground tanks located outdoors).   

The San Jose Creek Water Reclamation Plant West (SJCWRP West) is located at 1971 Workman Mill Road in Whittier, California 90601.  The SJCWRP West facility stores a maximum of 72,000-pounds of chlorine at any one time (contained in two 25-ton bulk storage containers located indoors), a maximum of 68,000 pounds of sulfur dioxide at any one time (contained in two 20-ton bulk storage containers located indoors), and a maximum of 85,000 pounds of aqueous ammonia (19.5 percent concentration) at any one time (contained in two 6,180 gallon above-ground tanks located outdoors).   

Due to the quantities of chlorine, sulfur dioxide and aqueous ammonia stored, handled and used at the site, SJCWRP is subject to requirements specified in the federal Risk Management Plan regulations (Code of Federal Regulations, Title 40, Part 68), the California Accidental Release Prevention Program regulations (California Code of Regulations, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5, Articles 1 through 11) and the federal Occupational Safety and Health AdministrationA?s Process Safety Management regulations (29 CFR Part 1910.119

).  

General Facility Information 

The primary operation conducted at the San Jose Creek Water Reclamation Plant is the treatment of wastewater (NAICS Code 22132 A? Sewage Treatment Facilities).  

The San Jose Creek Water Reclamation Plant (SJWRP) is located on two sites as follows:

A?    San Jose Creek Water Reclamation Plant A? East
    1965 Workman Mill Road
    Whittier, California 90601.  

A?    San Jose Creek Water Reclamation Plant A? West
    1971 Workman Mill Road
    Whittier, California 90601.  

The treatment facilities are located on a land area of approximately 39 acres, bounded on the southwest by the Pomona (60) Freeway, on the southeast side by Workman Mill Road, on the northeast side by the San Jose Creek Channel, and on the northwest side by the San Gabriel River.  

CSDLAC has operated the SJCWRP facility since inception in 1971.  The design treatment capacity of the plant has increased in stages, from an original capacity of 37.5 million gallons of wastewater per day (mgd) to the current capacity of 100 mgd.  The wastewater treated at SJCWRP originates mainly from approximately 1,000,000 domestic users in the San Gabriel Valley region; a small fraction is of industrial origin.  Wastewater treatment utilizes the activated sludge process with aqueous ammonia addition, chlorination, and dechlorination to yield a tertiary effluent that is suitable for re-use.  Aqueous ammonia (19.5 percent concentration) is used in the disinfection process.  

RMP Executive Summary Components

Storing and handling large quantities of aqueous ammonia, chlorine, and sulfur dioxide can create hazardous situations.  For this reason, SJCWRP follows all industry recommended practices for safely storing and handling these chemicals.  SJCWRPA?s aqueous ammonia handling processes are subject to the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program Level 2 Requirements.  SJCWRPA?s chlorine and sulfur dioxide handling processes are subject to the U.S. Environmental Protection Agenc

y (EPA) Risk Management Program and Plan and also to the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program Level 3 Requirements.  These Programs require a summary in the Risk Management Plan (RMP) of policies and procedures followed to safely operate the facility, including a description of the possible consequences in case of an accident and the actions which will be taken by the facility in an event of an emergency.  The following information is specifically required in the RMP Executive Summary: 
A?    Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies.
A?    General facility and regulated substances information.
A?    Offsite consequence analysis results. 
A?    Summary of the accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps.
A?    Five-year accident history summary.
A?    Emergency response program summary.
A?    Planned changes to improve safety.

This information is provided below.  

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

CSDLACA?s accidental release prevention policy at SJCWRP involves a unified approach that integrates proven technology, trains staff in operation and maintenance practices, and uses tested and proven management system practices.  All applicable procedures of the State of California and EPAA?s Prevention Program are adhered to, including key elements such as training, systems management, and emergency response procedures.  

The CSDLAC emergency response policy involves the preparation of Hazardous Materials and Hazardous Waste Consolidated Contingency Plans (HMHWCCP) for handling hazardous materials which are specific for each facility and to the emergency response services available in the community, and is in compliance with the EPA and CalARP Program Emergency Response Program Requirements.  The CSDLAC has prepared a HMHWCCP for the SJCWRP for storing and handling hazardous materials, including aqueous ammonia, chlorine, and sulfur dioxide to facilitate coordination and emergency planning

with offsite response officials and facilities in the event of an emergency.  The HMHWCCP has been coordinated with the local response agency (County of Los Angeles Fire Department).  The SJCWRP has an excellent record in preventing accidents from occurring.

Regulated Substance Information

Aqueous ammonia (19.5 percent concentration) is used to maintain the disinfection limits in the treated effluent.  The aqueous ammonia is provided by delivery truck and transferred via hose to the ammonia storage tanks. Throughout the documentation, aqueous ammonia is referred to as being stored in storage tanks; the aqueous ammonia solution is actually stored in 30 psig design, ASME Code unfired pressure vessels.  There are three 6,180 gallon tanks at the SJCWRP-East Station and two 6,180 gallon tanks at the SJCWRP-West Station.  The working capacity of each tank is 5,120 gallons, and each tank is provided with a high level alarm.  The aqueous ammonia is then transferred from the storage tanks to dosing locations within the effluent channel and mixed.  Once the aqueous ammonia is mixed with the treated effluent, CalARP regulations no longer apply.

Anhydrous chlorine used for chlorination at the East and West plants is received in chlorine trailers and transferred to bulk storage tanks located inside the buildings.  Anhydrous sulfur dioxide used for dechlorination is also received at the East and West plants in sulfur dioxide trailers and transferred to storage tanks located inside the buildings.  The chlorination system at both plants consists of two chlorine bulk storage tanks, evaporators, chlorinators, residual analyzers, ejectors, diffusers, chlorine contact tanks, piping and other equipment.  The capacity of each chlorine bulk storage tank is 25 tons; however, the maximum quantity of chlorine present in a tank at any given time is only 18 tons.  In case of a major chlorine leak, the bulk storage tanks and the chlorine tank trailer can be isolated by the emergency shutoff

valves located on the piping downstream of the bulk storage tank manway and at the end of the flexible hoses that connect to the tank trailer.  There are emergency shutdown switches (push buttons) located at each door into the chlorine building, and on the chlorine shutdown (emergency) valve control panel located on the mezzanine of the chlorine transfer area.  On the chlorine shutdown (emergency) valve control panel, there are individual control switches for each valve.  All emergency shutdown valves can also be activated from the Plant Control Room. 

Chlorine gas detectors are used to detect a chlorine leak in the bulk storage and chlorinator rooms.  Upon detection of approximately 0.5 ppmv chlorine, the detectors will send a signal which will shut down the normal ventilation system to contain the chlorine gas within the chlorination and storage rooms.  The caustic scrubber system is automatically activated in the event of a chlorine leak.

The sulfur dioxide system at both plants consists of two sulfur dioxide bulk storage tanks, evaporators, sulfonators, residual analyzers, ejectors, diffusers, and piping and other equipment.  The capacity of each sulfur dioxide bulk storage tank is 20 tons; however, the maximum quantity of sulfur dioxide present in a tank at any given time is only 17 tons. In case of a major sulfur dioxide leak, the bulk storage tanks and the sulfur dioxide tank trailer can be isolated by the emergency shutoff valves located on the piping downstream of the bulk storage tank manway.  In addition, emergency shutoff valves are located at the end of each of the flexible hoses that connect to the tank trailer at SJCWRP-East, and at the end of the sulfur dioxide gas and airpad flexible hoses at SJCWRP-West.  Installation of another emergency shutoff valve, located at the end of the sulfur dioxide liquid hose that connects to the tank trailer at SJCWRP-West, was completed by August 1999.  Similar to the chlorine system, there are emergency shutdown

switches on the sulfur dioxide system.

Sulfur dioxide gas detectors are used to detect a sulfur dioxide leak in the bulk storage room and sulfonator room.  Upon detection of approximately 5 ppmv sulfur dioxide, the detectors will send a signal, which will shut down the normal ventilation system to contain the gas within the sulfonator and storage room.  The caustic scrubber system is automatically activated in the event of a sulfur dioxide leak.

The scrubber systems at both plants are equipped with emergency generator sets.  The emergency generator will automatically start powering in the event of a power failure and will continue to run for 5 minutes after regular power is restored.  The emergency generator powers the entire scrubbing system including, local alarms, the scrubber fan (SJCWRP-East only), caustic recirculation pumps, electrically-operated valves and the sump pump.  The generator also powers portions of the chlorine and sulfur dioxide systems including the automatic shutoff valve system (including the air compressors), lighting in both areas as well as lighting in the scrubber area, gas detectors, and the building ventilation fans. 

The SJCWRP-East is manned 24 hours a day, year round.  Access to the plant is through gates which are closed after regular hours.  The SJCWRP-West is manned 8 hours per day, and during the other 16 hours per day, alarms are answered by the SJCWRP-East operators.

Offsite Consequence Analysis Results

The offsite consequence analysis includes consideration of both "worst-case release scenarios" and "alternative release scenarios" as mandated by the regulations.  The first scenario is defined by EPA, which states that "the owner or operator shall assume that the ... maximum quantity in the largest vessel ... is released as a gas over 10-minutes," due to an unspecified failure.  The alternative release scenario is defined as "more likely to occur than the worst case release scenario".

RMP and CalARP regulations for Program

2 and 3 processes require the performance of a consequence analysis for one worst-case release scenario that is estimated to create the greatest distance in any direction to a toxic endpoint resulting from an accidental release of regulated toxic substances from covered processes.  For the worst-case release scenario analysis for the SJCWRP, the following scenarios were considered: (1) rupture of one aqueous ammonia storage tank with a maximum capacity of 5,100 gallons at SJCWRP-East, (2) rupture of one aqueous ammonia tank with a maximum capacity of 5,100 gallons at SJCWRP-West, (3) rupture of one chlorine tank with a maximum capacity of 18-tons, resulting in a release of 36,000 pounds of chlorine over a 10-minute duration, at SJCWRP-East, (4) rupture of one chlorine tank with a maximum capacity of 18-tons, resulting in a release of 36,000 pounds of chlorine over a 10-minute duration, at SJCWRP-West, (5) rupture of one sulfur dioxide tank with a maximum capacity of 17-tons, resulting in a release of 34,000 pounds of sulfur dioxide over a 10-minute duration, at SJCWRP-East, and (6) rupture of one sulfur dioxide tank with a maximum capacity of 17-tons, resulting in a release of 34,000 pounds of sulfur dioxide over a 10-minute duration, at SJCWRP-West.

The aqueous ammonia tanks are located within a diked area.  The diked area for SJCWRP-East is 585.2 ft2 and for SJCWRP-West it is 635.47 ft2.  Hence, the release rates for aqueous ammonia at SJCWRP-East/West were calculated to be 1518.0 pounds per hour and 1638.0 pounds per hour, respectively.

Administrative controls are used to limit the filling of the chlorine bulk tank to only 18-tons and sulfur dioxide tank to 17-tons. The release rate reduction from the enclosed building is estimated to be approximately 82% of the release rate from the bulk tank, per guidance from EPA regarding control efficiencies levels for buildings storing chlorine and sulfur dioxide.  The release rates for chlorine and sulfur dioxide were t

is reviewed by affected staff and added or used to revise operating and maintenance procedures.

Five-year Accident History Summary

During the five years immediately preceding the Year 2009 Five Year RMP Update and Revalidation, no accidents involving aqueous ammonia, chlorine, or sulfur dioxide releases that could have caused safety or health hazard (deaths, injuries, property or environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place) have occurred at the SJCWRP (since 2004).

Emergency Response Program Summary

SJCWRP-trained operators are first responders to aqueous ammonia, chlorine, and sulfur dioxide leak alarms and accidental releases.  Operators from SJCWRP-East respond to accidental releases at SJCWRP-West when operators are not present after hours at the West plant.  Depending on the severity of the accidental release, external resources such as the Los Angeles County Fire Department will be called upon to aid in handling an aqueous ammonia, chlorine, or sulfur dioxide release.  As part of the emergency response program, the CSDLAC have developed and implemented Hazardous Materials and Hazardous Waste Consolidated Contingency Plans (HMHWCCPs) for SJCWRP-East and SJCWRP-West for the purpose of protecting public health and the environment.  The HMHWCCPs have been coordinated with the local response agency (Los Angeles County Fire Department).  The main elements of each emergency response plan are: (1) initial discovery equipment and procedure, (2) response to an emergency, including procedures for immediate action and internal notifications, (3) procedures for external notifications, including coordination with Local Governments, Incident Commanders, (4) incident action plan, including mitigation actions, response resources, (5) implementation of tactical plan, and (6) termination and follow-up actions.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

In 1990, as part of its compliance with the California Risk Management and Prevention Program (RMPP), numerous change

hus estimated to be 662 pounds per minute and 625 pounds per minute (lbs/min), respectively.  The released gas/liquid (i.e., either chlorine or sulfur dioxide) is assumed to form a denser-than-air cloud consisting of either chlorine/sulfur dioxide vapor and liquid droplets (aerosols) that disperse in the atmosphere.  Ammonia vapor from an evaporating pool does not form a denser-than-air cloud.  The distance to the toxic endpoint for aqueous ammonia was estimated using an average of results obtained from the SLAB and ALOHA dispersion analysis models and EPAA?s Dense Gas Air Dispersion (DEGADIS 2.1) Model for chlorine and sulfur dioxide.  The toxic endpoint selected by EPA and CalARP for aqueous ammonia is 200 ppm, which is the Emergency Response Planning Guideline Level 2 (ERPG-2).  The toxic endpoint selected by EPA and CalARP for both chlorine and sulfur dioxide is 3 ppm, which is also the Emergency Response Planning Guideline Level 2 (ERPG-2).  The toxic endpoint was conservatively set by EPA to ensure public notification and that local emergency response planning takes into account the greatest possible impacted area surrounding the release point.  In practice, this type of a total failure of bulk storage tanks would be unlikely.  EPA-mandated meteorological conditions, namely atmospheric Stability Class F, wind speed of 1.5 meter per second, highest daily maximum temperature (111 deg F), and average relative humidity (64%) were used for the worst-case release scenario analysis.  The results of the air dispersion analysis indicated that the toxic endpoint distance would be 2.7-miles for sulfur dioxide, 2.6 miles for chlorine and 0.11 miles for aqueous ammonia.  

RMP and CalARP rules require that a scenario which results in offsite toxic endpoint distance and is more likely to occur than the worst-case scenario should be selected as the alternative release scenario, unless no such scenario exists.  Unlike the worst-case scenario, the alternative release scenario

may consider active mitigation such as automatic shutoff valves, excess flow valves, and containment with scrubbers. Active mitigation is defined as requiring mechanical, electrical, or human input.

The alternative release scenarios must consider the facility accident history and/or failure scenarios identified in the process hazard analysis.  A review of the past five-year accident history data for the aqueous ammonia, chlorination, and dechlorination facilities pursuant to these rules indicated that there were no aqueous ammonia, chlorine, or sulfur dioxide releases, which could have resulted in offsite (outside the SJCWRP boundary) toxic endpoint distances.  Similarly, no credible accident scenario was identified from the process hazard analysis, which would reach offsite.  Thus, an acceptable/credible alternative release scenario had to be selected based on expert judgment.  The following alternative scenarios were selected for the offsite consequence analysis: 

The alternative release scenario selected for the SJCWRP ammonia system involves the transfer of the ammonia from the delivery truck to the tank.  A breach in the 20 foot transfer hose with an inside diameter of 2 inches is used as the alternative release.  In addition, the delivery truck operator or supervising facility personnel is assumed to have a reaction time of 60 seconds, at which point the emergency shut-off switch will be activated to stop the aqueous ammonia release.  Hence, the amount of aqueous ammonia released is equal to the volume of the hose as well as the amount released during the operatorA?s reaction time.  The amount released during the operatorsA? reaction time is equal to 60 seconds multiplied by the fill transfer pump flow rate of 100 gpm.  It was estimated that approximately 861.3 pounds is the amount of aqueous ammonia liquid could be released during this alternative release scenario.

The alternative release scenarios selected for the SJCWRP chlorination and dechlorination sy

stems at the East and West facilities involve the release of chlorine/sulfur dioxide from the monel flexible hose connecting the storage tanks to chlorination and dechlorination processes.  These scenarios can occur if the operator uses a flex hose, which is worn or has a defect, which results in a crack in the flex hose during the withdrawal of chlorine/sulfur dioxide from the storage tanks.  It is assumed that the crack developed in the flex hose (diameter 1-inch) corresponds to a hole of 0.1875-inch (3/16 inch) diameter.  The control room would have been warned of the chlorine/sulfur dioxide leak by the chlorine/sulfur dioxide detectors installed at the chlorination/dechlorination facility.  It is assumed that a maximum of sixty minutes would be required for operators or an emergency response team to respond and activate the remotely-controlled shutoff valves installed on the flex hoses.

The chlorine release rate inside the storage room was estimated at 87 lb/min.  However, the chlorine release rate to the atmosphere from the scrubber would be only 0.003 lb/min. The sulfur dioxide release rate inside the storage room was estimated at 56 lb/min.  However, the sulfur dioxide release rate to the atmosphere from the scrubber would be only 0.01 lb/min.  Since the chlorine and sulfur dioxide release from the scrubber stacks would be neutrally buoyant, EPAA?s SCREEN3 model was used for the air dispersion analysis.  

The meteorological conditions used for the alternative release scenario analysis were Stability D, wind speed of 3.0 meters per second, average air temperature of 64 deg F, and average humidity of 64%.  The results of the aqueous ammonia dispersion modeling analysis were calculated based on the average of the SLAB and ALOHA results.  The results indicated that the maximum ground level ten minute average concentration for aqueous ammonia would reach the toxic endpoint of 200 ppm.  This concentration would only extend for 0.08 miles.  The results of the SCRE

EN3 dispersion modeling analysis indicated that the maximum ground level one-hour average concentration for chlorine and sulfur dioxide would be less than 0.1 ppm (0.02 ppm for chlorine and 0.06 ppm for sulfur dioxide).  These concentrations are significantly lower than 3 ppm, the toxic endpoints for chlorine and sulfur dioxide, and will have no offsite impacts.

It may be noted that the occurrence of the chlorine and sulfur dioxide scenarios are highly unlikely because the flex hoses are inspected and pressure tested every two years. 

Summary of the Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

SJCWRP is in compliance with Federal and State Process Safety Management requirements. SJCWRP accidental release prevention program is based on the following key elements: 
A?    Detailed management system and clear levels of responsibilities and team member roles.
A?    Comprehensive process safety information that is readily available to staff, emergency responders, and contractors.
A?    Comprehensive preventive maintenance program.
A?    Performance of process hazard analysis of equipment and procedures with operation and maintenance staff participation and review.
A?    Use of state-of-the-art process and safety equipment.
A?    Use of accurate and effective operating procedures, written with the participation of the operators.
A?    High level of training of the operators and maintenance staff.
A?    Implementation of an incident investigation, inspection, and auditing program using qualified staff.
Chemical-specific prevention steps include the awareness of the hazardous and toxic properties of aqueous ammonia and the remotely-controlled shutoff valves on the ammonia transfer trucks.  Chemical-specific prevention steps include the use of supplied air respirators (SAR) and self-contained breathing apparatus (SCBA), worn by the operators during connection/disconnection of chlorine/sulfur dioxide supply, the use of air purifying respirators (APR) worn by the dri

vers during connection/disconnection of chlorine/sulfur dioxide supply and availability of SCBA to the drivers, awareness of the hazardous and toxic properties of chlorine/sulfur dioxide, presence of chlorine/sulfur dioxide detectors and alarms, remotely-controlled shutoff valves, and chlorine/sulfur dioxide scrubbers.

Process and Chemical Safety Information

Comprehensive chemical data have been assembled to include regulatory reporting and action thresholds, health hazard, and chemical exposure limitations, as well as detailed physical properties of aqueous ammonia, chlorine, and sulfur dioxide.  This information includes aqueous ammonia, chlorine, and sulfur dioxide background information and MSDS sheets. 

Equipment safety information was compiled on the aqueous ammonia, chlorine, and sulfur dioxide processes and is provided in one place for easy reference. Details such as maximum intended inventory; safe upper and lower temperatures; safe upper and lower pressures; and codes and standards used to design, build, and operate the processes are on file at the facility.  CSDLAC also has procedures in place that are triggered to update process safety information for SJCWRP if there is a change that makes existing information inaccurate.

Process Hazard Analysis 

In 1990, as part of its compliance with the California Risk Management and Prevention Program (RMPP), numerous changes to improve safety (recommended actions) were identified for the storage, handling and use of chlorine and sulfur dioxide as part of the PHAs conducted at the SJCWRP.  The PHAs conducted in 1990 were reviewed in 1997 under the RMPP and Process Safety Management (PSM) Program as part of an update. In 1999, as part of its compliance with the Federal RMP and California RMP programs CSDLAC conducted PHA updates for the storage, handling and use of chlorine and sulfur dioxide at SJCWRP.  Furthermore, in 2004, CSDLAC conducted a PHA on the storage, handling and use of aqueous ammonia at SJCWRP.  A

LL recommended actions resulting from these PHAs and PHA Updates have been implemented as required.  

As part of the Year 2009 Five Year RMP Update and Revalidation, PHA updates were conducted for the storage, handling and use of chlorine, sulfur dioxide and aqueous ammonia.  Based on this review, several additional recommended actions have been identified to further improve the safety of the chlorine, the sulfur dioxide and the aqueous ammonia systems.  The implementation of these recommendations will further improve the safety of these systems.  

Seismic risk assessments and walkthroughs of the chlorine, sulfur dioxide and aqueous ammonia storage, handling and use systems have also been conducted by CSDLAC.  This work was initially performed in 1999 for the chlorine and sulfur dioxide systems at both the East and West facilities and updated at various intervals. In 2009, CSDLAC prepared updated Seismic Risk Assessment Reports for the SJCWRP.  ALL updated seismic risk assessment work was performed in conformance with the Guidance for California Accidental Release Prevention Program (CalARP) Seismic Assessments.

It should be noted that all corrective actions previously recommended have been completed (i.e., closed out) and verified.

Operating Procedures

The CSDLAC WRP section maintains up-to-date, accurate, written operating procedures for the SJCWRP that provide clear instructions for aqueous ammonia, chlorine, and sulfur dioxide processes.  CSDLAC ensures effective operating practices by combining them with operating and maintenance training programs. Standard operating procedures (SOPs) provide system descriptions, specifications, equipment inspection requirements, and operating procedures for the aqueous ammonia, chlorine, and sulfur dioxide systems.  The operating procedures include start-up, normal operation, shutdown, and non-standard operating procedures.  Also included are the maintenance and troubleshooting procedures.  CSDLAC updates procedures whene

ver a change occurs that alters the steps needed to operate safely.  Operating procedures are developed and put in place prior to any new process equipment coming on line or changes made in the handling of aqueous ammonia, chlorine, or sulfur dioxide equipment, and reconfiguration of the facilities.

Training

SJCWRP employees presently involved in operating or maintaining the aqueous ammonia, chlorine, and sulfur dioxide processes are trained in an overview of the process and detailed applicable operating and maintenance procedures. CSDLAC ensures that each SJCWRP employee newly assigned to the process is trained and tested to be competent in the operating procedures listed pertaining to their duties. SJCWRP training program includes four elements: (1) initial training, (2) refresher training, (3) documentation, and (4) and testing.  Each employee (presently involved in operating the aqueous ammonia, chlorine, and sulfur dioxide processes) has been trained with the required knowledge, skills, and abilities to safely carry out the duties and responsibilities, including aqueous ammonia, chlorine, and sulfur dioxide emergency response, as provided in the Hazardous Materials and Hazardous Wastes Consolidated Contingency Plan. 

Refresher training is provided annually to each employee operating the covered process to ensure that the employee understands and adheres to the current operating procedures.  Operators at SJCWRP are also provided quarterly refresher training on current safety procedures.  In addition, the CSDLAC ensures that operators and maintenance personnel at SJCWRP are trained in any updated or new procedures prior to startup of a process after a major change as indicated in their Management of Change procedures.

CSDLAC prepares and retains records of initial and refresher training, provides certification of the records, which includes the identity of the employee, the date of training, and the signature of the person(s) administering the training. 

Con

tractors

Contractors are properly informed of the hazards, access limitations to these process areas, and emergency response procedures.  The contractors are informed, prior to the initiation of the work at the site, of the applicable provisions of the emergency response plan.  CSDLAC Field Engineering and Environmental Health & Safety Section holds contractor safety briefings before allowing them near or in the process areas, control access to the process areas, and evaluate the contractorA?s performance. 

It should be noted that Program 2 processes (e.g., aqueous ammonia) do not need to adhere to CalARP A?ContractorA? provisions.

Pre-Startup Safety Review and Mechanical Integrity Program

CSDLAC WRP Section ensures that a pre-startup safety review is completed for any new covered-by-the-rules process, or for significant modifications to an existing covered process at SJCWRP that requires a change in the process safety information.  CSDLAC maintains the mechanical integrity of process equipment at SJCWRP to help prevent equipment failures that could endanger workers, the public, or the environment.  CSDLAC mechanical integrity program for SJCWRP includes the following:  
A?    Written procedures for maintaining mechanical integrity through inspection and testing of process equipment, based on instructions of equipment vendors, industry standards, and prior operating experience.
A?    Implementation of the written procedures by performing inspections and tests on process equipment at specified intervals.
A?    Training of maintenance personnel in preventive maintenance program procedures; safe work practices such as lockout/tagout, line or equipment opening, and avoidance and correction of unsafe conditions; and safe use and application of special equipment and/or unique tools.
It should be noted that Program 2 processes (e.g., aqueous ammonia) do not need to adhere to CalARP A?Pre-Startup Safety ReviewA? provisions

Hot Work Permits and Management of Change 

CSDLAC requ

ires employees and contractors to employ safe work practices when performing hot work in, on, or around a covered process at SJCWRP.  SJCWRP uses a permitting program to ensure hot work is conducted safely on or near a process involving chlorine and sulfur dioxide.

CSDLAC provides a system and approach to maintain and implement any management of change or modifications to equipment, procedures, chemicals, and processing conditions at SJCWRP. This system allows CSDLAC staff to identify and review safety hazards or provide additional safety, process, or chemical information to existing data before the proposed change would either compromise safety or need training to be completed.

It should be noted that Program 2 processes (e.g., aqueous ammonia) do not need to adhere to CalARP A?Management of ChangeA? provisions.

Internal Compliance Audits

Internal compliance audits are conducted every 3 years to verify compliance with the programs and procedures contained in the RMP.  This process involves CSDLAC  assembling an audit team that includes personnel knowledgeable in the Risk Management Program rule and in the process.  This team will evaluate whether the prevention program satisfies the requirements of the Risk Management Program rule and whether the prevention program is sufficient to help ensure safe operation of the process.  The results of the audit are documented, recommendations resolved, and appropriate enhancements to the prevention program are implemented.

Incident Investigation

CSDLAC investigates all incidents that could reasonably have resulted in a catastrophic release (serious injury to personnel, the public, or the environment) so that similar accidents can be prevented.  An investigation team is assembled and the investigation is initiated within 48 hours of the incident.
